node.title: Default computer core?
node.bodyText:
Hi, I am trying to figure out the computational expense of the calculation. When I am runing a case, I use the command 'myapp-opt -i input.i' without any other specification. Does it mean I am using the default core? How many computer core I am using? Can I use more cores to shorter the calculation time?
Thank you very much for any help.

Hi,
You can use following command to set core numbers, the nomber after "n" shows core numbers, here for example it is 6 :
mpirun -n 6 ./AppName-opt -i input.i
Rahim

Thank you so much for the information.
Besides, do you have any idea on how to check the core number I am using now? I didn't specify any core numbers, just want to know the defult value (if there was one).

In the calculation header you can look at the number of processes used.
By default you are using 1

Got it.
Thank you very much!

node.title: Define domain with multiple material functions
node.bodyText: I am currently using, type = ADGenericConstantMaterial,   prop_names = 'rho mu cp k'. I would like to define each of the materials with an analytical function. is there something similar to ADGenericConstantMaterial that allows me to define rho mu cp k, with an analytical function for each?

Hello
you can use GenericFunctionMaterial for functions of time and space.
For analytical functions of things like variables you may use the ParsedMaterial
Guillaume
Thank you very much. I thought that GenericFunctionMaterial might be the used for that, but I was not sure of the syntax and the ability to define a function for multiple entities. Thanks again!
Yeah it can. The big limitation to functions is that, without additional code, are only functions of space and time
What do most users use when they want to vary material properties as functions of defined variables?

If you have a simple expression you can write in an input files, the ParsedMaterial
if not then you ll have to make your own material, using C++ code. The tutorial explains how

It appears that these (Material property 'rho', requested by 'ins_mat' is not defined on block Coolant
Material property 'rho', requested by 'ins_mat_face' is not defined on block Coolant
Material property 'rho', requested by 'ins_mat_neighbor' is not defined on block Coolant
Material property 'rho', requested by 'mass_pspg' is not defined on block Coolant
) expect that material properties be defined in from ADGenericConstantMaterial is preventing my use of ParsedMaterial to specify rho as a function of temperature.

You can only specify a property once.
You also need to be consistent with using AD. So you ll want to use an ADParsedMaterial most likely

Yep. I figured that would probably be the cause for the issue. I tried the command using AD, and it is what resulted in the previous issue I shared. I removed rho as a definition in the ADConst defined it in the ADParsed. The other portions of AD did not recognize rho as being defined.
can you please paste your former and current Materials block?

[Materials] # Old
  [./const]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'rho mu cp k'
    prop_values = '1000  0.001 4179.0  0.598' #[kg/m^3*1e-9] [Pa*sec*1e-6] [J/kg/K*1e6] [W/m/K*1e3] non exponential forms
  [../]
  [ins_mat]
    type = INSADStabilized3Eqn
    velocity = velocity
    pressure = p
    temperature = T_fluid
  []
[]

[Materials] # New
  [./const]
    type = ADGenericConstantMaterial
    prop_names = 'mu cp k'
#    prop_values = '0.001 4179.0  0.598' #[kg/m^3*1e-9] [Pa*sec*1e-6] [J/kg/K*1e6] [W/m/K*1e3] non exponential forms 
  [../]
  [./rho_density]
    type = ADParsedMaterial
    property_name = 'rho'
    coupled_variables = 'T_fluid'
    function = '99.98*((1.000088*(T_fluid-283.2))/(1-(p-1.0e5)/2.15e9))'
#    outputs = exodus
  [../]
  [ins_mat]
    type = INSADStabilized3Eqn
    velocity = velocity
    pressure = p
    temperature = T_fluid
  []
[]

what error are you getting?
This looks right, except it should be: expression = '99.98*((1.000088*(T_fluid-283.2))/(1-(p-1.0e5)/2.15e9))'

oh is your MOOSE old?
if so property_name is not the name of the parameter, it s still called f_name in an old version of MOOSE
property_name would return an unused parameter warning
Yes, the version on this system is old, and I have to switch between expression and function when moving from one computer to the other.

You ll have to use the old parameters. property-name is not recognized, so the default for f_name is being used.
so instead of declaring rho you are declaring a property as F and naturally getting an error

This is the error that I get when I use T_fluid in the definition of rho:
*** ERROR ***
Invalid function
99.98*((1.000088*(T_fluid-283.2))/(1-(p-1.0e5)/2.15e9))
in ParsedMaterialHelper.
Syntax error: Unknown identifier

you need to adapt all the parameters
All your neew syntax parameters are not recognized
you should have args = 'p T_fluid'
My apologies upfront for not having mastered how to prevent the super large fonts.
no worries. I use the triple backquotes to do that

Had to remove the reference to T_fluid, and it got me further in the processing chain. I now get this error instead:
*** ERROR ***
/home/twise/projects/moose/modules/combined/7x7PWR_Assembly/Models/CoolantVelocityPWR.i:217: unused parameter 'Materials/rho_density/coupled_variables'

should be args, not coupled_variables.
You can add T and p back once you have that fixed

node.title: Why does FSP report an error you must have exactly 2 fields？
node.bodyText:
Hello, everyone!
When I used FSP preprocessing, the following error occurred. How can I correct it? Thank you very much！

Hello
The Schur decomposition is well defined for two groups of variable, but has not been extended to more than that
if you want more splits than two groups then you need to use a multipliciative or additive field split instead of Schur.
They may not converge as well from our experience
Guillaume

node.title: Laser welding with Baldr/MALAMUTE
node.bodyText:
Hi,
I need to simulate laser welding and melt pool formation with fluid flow and surface deformation like the example given on Moose homepage. Is it possible to employ ALE using the current moose version to do this?
Following a discussion here, I understood that this example was simulated in Baldr or Malamute. Is is possible to get access to that?
Regards.
@jiangwen84 will know more but I think the situation has not changed since this other post.

Thanks @GiudGiud. I actually applied for an INL HPC account stating the reason that I need access to MALAMUTE, but my application was denied. I was told that NCRC doesn't manage MALAMUTE but it is the Technology Department (also cc'd in that email) that manages this and can advise on how to obtain the code. I then contacted the Technology Department but haven't heard anything from them since.
Do you have any more info @jiangwen84 or @cticenhour ?
Thanks!

Getting the INL HPC account through the NCRC is still the way to get started, as MALAMUTE access is not possible without an account. INL is closed for the holiday season, which may be why you haven't gotten a reply from Technology Deployment. I can check in on this in January, once INL is back to work.

Thanks @cticenhour. My application for an account on INL HPC was denied because of the reason I stated above. But I can wait for an answer from Technology Deployment, and if then needed I'll re-apply for the HPC account.
Happy holidays!
Any update on this @am-tc01 ?

Did you send another email to them after the holidays? Your old email may have gotten left behind in their inbox, so it's worth giving them a reminder that you're waiting. Also, if I need to follow up with them directly, I would need more information from you - like, your current university/institution and name.

Hi @cticenhour
I have now sent an email to Technology Deployment and cc'ed you as well.
Hope to hear back from them soon.
Thanks!
Hi, Just wondering if there is any update on this @cticenhour?
Spoke to the manager over the NCRC, and am working on resurrecting your case on my end. Will let you know when I know more.

Hi again - you should have received an email a bit ago regarding MALAMUTE access from the NCRC. I am CC-ed on that email message, so please feel free to reach out directly if you have other issues. Thanks again for your interest in MALAMUTE!

@am-tc01 Good news - MALAMUTE is now open source and can be found at https://github.com/idaholab/malamute.
Given this new status for MALAMUTE, do you still require INL HPC access? Please advise. Thanks!

Hi @cticenhour Thanks for the info. Yes that is indeed a good news!
No, I wouldn't require INL HPC access anymore. I'll reply to their email as well.
On a separate note, I have already started looking into the MALAMUTE code and tried to run some of the examples. Some of them worked, but some didn't converge and few gave errors. But perhaps I can create separate tickets for those in the Malamute discussion forum.
Yes, please open a discussion on the MALAMUTE repository for any examples that aren't running as expected.

node.title: Magnitude of the gradient of the unknown variable
node.bodyText:
Hello everyone,
I need to get the magnitude of the gradient of the unknown variable (abs(_grad_u)) to compute the residual term in the weak form of the equation. Is there any available object so I can get the abs(_grad_u) or I should do it myself?
Thanks,
Ali

Hello
don’t think we have that one but you could save the gradient in an intermediate aux variable, then use another auxkernel to get the magnitude of the vector.
It will only cost a little bit of extra memory to do that
Guillaume

  [../]
[./modenum]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    f_name = mnum
    args = 'eta1 eta2'
    function = 'if(eta1>=0.5 & eta2 <0.5, 1,1)'
  [../]
  [./referneceangle]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    f_name = reangle
    args = 'eta1 eta2'
    function = 'if(eta1>=0.5 & eta2 <0.5, 0,0)'
  [../]
 [./anisotropicstre]
    type = ParsedMaterial
    f_name = abstre
    args = 'eta1 eta2'
    function = 'if(eta1>=0.5 & eta2 <0.5, 1,1)'
  [../]

ANisotropic file:
InputParameters
ANisotropicForth::validParams()
{
  InputParameters Params = Material::validParams();
  Params.addClassDescription("anistropy_function");
  Params.addRequiredParam<MaterialPropertyName>(
		"anisotropy_strength", "strengthen value");
  Params.addRequiredParam<MaterialPropertyName>(
		"mode_number", "mode number for anisotropic");
  Params.addRequiredParam<MaterialPropertyName>(
		"reference_angle", "Reference angle for defining anisotropy in degrees");
  Params.addRequiredCoupledVar("op", "Order parameter ");
  return Params;
}

ANisotropicForth::ANisotropicForth(const InputParameters & Parameters)
	: Material(Parameters),
	// Get the parameters from the input file
	_delta(getMaterialProperty<Real>("anisotropy_strength")),
	_j(getMaterialProperty<Real>("mode_number")),
	_theta0(getMaterialProperty<Real>("reference_angle")),
	_fun(declareProperty<Real>("fun")),
	_dfun(declareProperty<Real>("dfun")),
	_d2fun(declareProperty<Real>("d2fun")),
	_dfundgrad_op(declareProperty<RealGradient>("dfundgrad_op")),
	_ddfundgrad_op(declareProperty<RealGradient>("ddfundgrad_op")),
	_op(coupledValue("op")),
	_grad_op(coupledGradient("op"))
{
	if (_mesh.dimension() != 2)
		mooseError("ANisotropicForth requires a two-dimensional mesh.");
}

void
ANisotropicForth::computeQpProperties()
{
	const Real tol = 1e-9;
	const Real cutoff = 1.0 - tol;
	// tagent of the gradient orientation angle
	Real n = 0.0;
	const Real nsq = _grad_op[_qp].norm_sq();
	if (nsq>tol)
		n = std::max(-cutoff, std::min((_grad_op[_qp](1) / _grad_op[_qp](0)) / std::sqrt(nsq), cutoff));

	// calculate angle
	const Real angle = std::atan2(_grad_op[_qp](1), _grad_op[_qp](0));

	// Compute derivative of angle wrt n
	const Real dangledn = MathUtils::sign((_grad_op[_qp](1)) / _grad_op[_qp](0)) / (1.0 + n * n);

	RealGradient dndgrad_op;
	if (nsq > tol)
	{
		dndgrad_op(0) = -2 * _grad_op[_qp](1) - _grad_op[_qp](1) * _grad_op[_qp](1) * _grad_op[_qp](1) / (_grad_op[_qp](0) * _grad_op[_qp](0));
		dndgrad_op(1) = _grad_op[_qp](0);
		dndgrad_op /= (_grad_op[_qp].norm_sq() * _grad_op[_qp].norm());
	}



	// Calculate  function of mobility

	_fun[_qp] = ((_delta[_qp] * std::pow(cos(_j[_qp] * (angle + _theta0[_qp] * libMesh::pi / 180)), 2.0) + 1.0) / (1.0 + _delta[_qp]));


	// Calculate interfacial parameter function  's derivatives  
	_dfun[_qp] = -_delta[_qp] * _j[_qp] * std::sin(2.0 * _j[_qp] * (angle + _theta0[_qp] * libMesh::pi / 180)) / (1.0 + _delta[_qp]);
	_d2fun[_qp] = -_delta[_qp] * _j[_qp] * _j[_qp] * 2.0 * std::cos(2.0 * _j[_qp] * (angle + _theta0[_qp] * libMesh::pi / 180)) / (1.0 + _delta[_qp]);



	// Compute derivatives of mobility and its derivative wrt grad_op
	_dfundgrad_op[_qp] = _dfun[_qp] * dangledn * dndgrad_op;
	_ddfundgrad_op[_qp] = _d2fun[_qp] * dangledn * dndgrad_op;

Hello
I think you need to have a look at the block/subdomain restriction of your materials, variables and IC.
The ics for eta1 and 2 are limited to one block one, and the two variables are defined everywhere? Same for the materials using these two variables.
Also the ParsedMaterial syntax is all deprecated. If you're using a recent MOOSE you should be getting warnings from that
Guillaume

Thank you for your reply. I used the MOOSE platform based on Ubuntu22.04, and there was no warning. If the ParsedMaterial syntax has been deprecated, is there a tutorial on the alternative syntax on the website?

The updated parameters can be seen here
https://mooseframework.inl.gov/source/materials/ParsedMaterial.html
Your MOOSE must be more than like 2 months old then.
It's ok, you dont need to update to fix this.
What is the error message exactly?
Which property is missing?

The specific information is:
The following error occurred in the object "MOOSE Problem", of type "FEproblem".
Material property 'anstre', requested by 'mobility2' is not defined on block 1.
Material property 'anstre', requested by 'mobility_2_face' is not defined on block 1.
Material property 'anstre', requested by 'mobility_2_neighbor' is not defined on block 1.
Material property 'anstre', requested by 'mobility2' is not defined on block 2.
Material property 'anstre', requested by 'mobility_2_face' is not defined on block 2.
Material property 'anstre', requested by 'mobility_2_neighbor' is not defined on block 2.
But I managed to compile the ANisotropicforth.C file, and I didn't find that I had to define BLOCK areas when I was referring to other C files.
You spelled it abstre instead of anstre in the parsed material called anisotropicstre
Ah, I just saw that it can run after I modified it. Thank you for your help.

Guillaume
Hi @GiudGiud. Thanks for the suggestion. I increased my l_max_its to 100 and it still gives me error. I even tried 200 w/o success.
ok. Next I would double check that all variables are well initialized and that block restrictions are all correct. If you forgot physics on one block that will impede convergence

I haven't explored your input file in lots of detail, but a couple of things stood out to me:

the porosity is zero in one of the blocks.  Is this a mistake?  It will mean that the porous-flow physics immediately goes to steadystate in that block, which is always numerically harder than a time-varying situation.  I wonder whether your model would truly exhibit unphysical results if you made that block a little bit porous, and helped the numerics a bit?
your Young's modulus in one block is O(1E11), but is O(1E-9) in another block.  That will probably mean the linear system is difficult to solve numerically, which is the problem you are encountering.  Computers just don't like to solve Ax=b when parts of A are O(1E11) and other parts are O(1E-9).  Again, i suspect your model won't exhibit unphysical results if you change your 1E-9 to 1E6, but might give nicer convergence.

These might not be the solution - just a couple of things i noticed

This simulation is a benchmark with the parameters taken from https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijrmms.2021.104879. Their simulation seems to converge.

your Young's modulus in one block is O(1E11), but is O(1E-9) in another block

Also, please note that, in the input file above, I did not apply displacement BCs to the casing, the fluid block and the injection area (red block in my model). However, even when I assigned these BCs, I got no convergence. Thanks.

Hello @WilkAndy, My simulation finally converges, and you’re right! The results don’t make any physical sense. It converges even at a zero porosity value but not without setting a large value for Young’s modulus (E=1e11). I guess the problem is with my Young’s Modulus. In the publication, both E and v are practically zero in the fluid block, making the fluid have practically no mechanical constitutive behaviour. I wonder whether that is the problem besides the steady-state solution for the casing. I’m sending an email to the corresponding author of the publication. Hopefully, I’ll get answers. In the meantime,  I’d be glad if you could comment on my BCs in reference to the description in the publication. Thanks a lot!

That is, put
[Variables]
  [pwater]
    initial_condition = 101325         #1e5
    block = 'rocksalt fluid injection_region'
  []

You may then get a bunch of errors, which will lead you to include   block = 'rocksalt fluid injection_region' in other places too (AuxVariables, Materials, etc).
By the way, since your initial stress is isotropic, you could use RZ coordinates to make this heaps more computationally efficient.
Also, if the impermeable casing completely encloses the fluid_injection_region then you'll get no hydraulic connection to the rocksalt region: the only reason the porepressure in the rocksalt region will increase is because the casing pushes mechanically on it.   Seems like a strange problem - usually casings are perforated in some way which allows fluid to move in and out of the wellbore.

You are absolutely right! At least from my understanding, the wellbore in the model from the publication is ‘cased’ up to a certain length, and the remaining length is open for fluid injection. See the red block in the model above. This red block is open without a casing, and the casing only covers the light blue block. I guess it is what makes this problem a bit peculiar. The left image is case 1 of the Kamlot percolation experiment from the publication. The right image is case 2. These are still preliminary results.

I'm glad you're getting somewhere.
RZ coordinates allow you to use a 2D model, with the horizontal axis representing the radial coordinate (r), and the vertical axis representing the vertical coordinate (z).  Being 2D it is so much faster than a 3D simulation.   Do
cd modules/porous_flow
find . -name "*.i" | xargs grep RZ

and you'll find quite a few examples.  Near the bottom of https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/porous_flow/tutorial_11.html you'll see instructions on how to convert a 3D to a 2D-RZ problem in a very similar situation to what you're studying.
Even if you end up doing something that doesn't have RZ symmetry (eg, if your insitu horizontal principal stresses are different) then before that the RZ will allow you to experiment with things much more easily because the simulation will converge much faster than the 3D case.

Thanks, Andy. I will use a 2D model in the RZ coordinate system then. Please, note that I was right about the fluid having practically no mechanics due to the values of E and v. The paper made this clear:

The fluid injection domain, i.e. the inner domain of the pipe, is treated as a porous medium with porosity and a Biot’s coefficient of 1 and a low Young’s modulus, practically leaving only the hydraulic interaction with the rock salt and the casing.

Since I can’t get the value of E to be practically zero, I’m now trying to ‘block-restrict’ the displacement variables so that the fluid block does not have any mechanics. My challenge, however, is that I can’t define displacement on a block without defining the advective flux or the mass time derivative on that block because I keep getting the following error:
*** ERROR ***
The 'block' parameter of the object 'time_derivative' must be a subset of the 'block' parameter of the variable 'disp_x':
    Object 'time_derivative': 37, 38, 39
    Variable 'disp_x': 36, 38

My question is: why is the block parameter of the advective Kernel linked to the block parameter of the displacement variable in PorousFlow? I’m finding it difficult to grasp because (in reality) the displacement variable is not part of the flux or mass time derivative physics/kernel. Thanks.

You can block restrict kernels as well.
Do you have a time_derivative kernel in your input file or is this being added by an action?

Hi @GiudGiud., Yeah. I have a time_derivative Kernel in my input file (i.e., PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative), which is not an action. Sure, I can block restrict kernels as well. I did that to the PorousFlowMassTimeDerivative Kernel and still got the same error messages.

How did you block restrict that kernel?
and what about the variable?
Please paste those parts of the input
The error message says it doesnt match

I know the symmetry boundary condition in x-direction is (disp_x = rot_y = rot_z = 0), but when I add rotations in GlobalParams by rotations = "rot_x rot_y rot_z", it says the variables "rot_x, rot_y and rot_z" can't be found. And if I only set disp_x to 0, the simulation results are totally wrong. The attached file is  my input file.
problems.zip

Hello
You should either create the rotation variables or find the Action that does that for you
@recuero @jiangwen84  do you know
Guillaume
I'd just add the rotation variables to the pertinent blocks --not to GlobalParams. That's the way most input files are set up as far as I can see.
Would you please explain this in more detail? I just looked at the examples of tensor mechanic module and couldn't find a relevant tutorial.

I cannot see any rotations in your attached problem and am not sure what you are trying to simulate or which elements you want to use. As @GiudGiud pointed out, the rotation variables can be created by actions. For rotation variables necessary for beams/trusses, the LineElementMaster action will do this for you. If you are wanting to use some other element you will need to create those variables and pass them appropriately to compute internal forces and apply BCs. For general tutorials, refer to https://mooseframework.inl.gov/getting_started/examples_and_tutorials/index.html. For particular examples on how to use variables in the tensor mechanics modules, you can consult https://mooseframework.inl.gov/modules/tensor_mechanics/index.html and browse relevant input files.

The symmetry boundary conditions should be applied to x-face(the face normal to x-direction) and z-face(the face normal to z-direction), which are named as inside1 and inside2 in my input file, respectively. Because it is an uni-axial tensile loading, I only set displacements of these faces to 0, but the results look weird.

Solid elements, with rare exceptions, do not have rotational variables. I don't think that the cause of the weirdness in your results is caused by rotational degrees of freedom. The BCs, as you describe them, look correct to me.
You have other objects in your input file, such as ComputeLodeAngle that I am not familiar with, nor can I find them in MOOSE. Could you maybe simplify your constitutive model and rerun the problem? You may see if your results make more sense with mere elastic behavior.
